bib: Altepeter, Lawrence J. “Choosing a Path to Glory: A Theory on Ascetical Performance Selection.” Ph.D. dissertation, Saint Louis University, 1999.
citation: Lawrence J. Altepeter, “Choosing a Path to Glory: A Theory on Ascetical Performance Selection” (Ph.D. dissertation, Saint Louis University, 1999).

data.title: Choosing a Path to Glory: A Theory on Ascetical Performance Selection
data.abstractNote:
While the Early Christian world may have stood in essential agreement on the value of asceticism, the ascetical life itself took on a multitude of forms as evidenced by the various Early Christian ascetics. In this dissertation I argue that Early Christian ascetics did not haphazardly choose the ascetical acts which they incorporated into their lives, but that each ascetical activity was intentionally selected. More precisely, my thesis is that ascetical performance selection was determined by an ascetic's theology, anthropology, and the envisioned goal towards which the ascetic strove; all of which was significantly conditioned by the immediate dominant culture.
After presenting a quick survey of contemporary ascetical thought and theory (chap.1), I establish the validity of my thesis by applying it to four different Early Christian ascetical texts: Athanasius' Vita Antonii (chap. 2), Basil of Caesarea's Requlae fusius tractatae (chap.3), Theodoret of Cyrrhus' "Life of Symeon the Stylite" (chap.4), and James of Edessa's Conversatio vel paenitentia sanctae Pelagiae (chap. 5). In all four texts the goal sought is eternal salvation, but the differing theological and anthropological underpinnings result in distinct ascetical lifestyles. The Vita Antonii 's apprehension of the demonic--coupled with Egypt's history of anachoresis --leads it to an askesis based upon eremitism. In Basil's text the primary focus is upon charity which directs it to a cenobitical askesis . Symeon, perched upon his pillar, demonstrates an askesis deeply entrenched within the Syrian ascetical traditions of mourning, physical mobility restriction and societal withdraw. In order to redirect her focus from her inherent carnality, the transvestite Pelagia dons the dress of a male monastic. Each of these four texts promote a specific form of askesis , reflective of the theological and anthropological premises which undergird them as well as the influences of the immediate dominant culture.

bib: Amar, Joseph Phillip. “Christianity at the Crossroads: The Legacy of Ephrem the Syrian.” Religion and Literature 43:2 (2011): 1–21.
citation: Joseph Phillip Amar, “Christianity at the Crossroads: The Legacy of Ephrem the Syrian,” Religion and Literature 43:2 (2011): 1–21.

data.title: Christianity at the Crossroads: The Legacy of Ephrem the Syrian
data.abstractNote: The Syriac Life of Ephrem purports to be a factual account of the most celebrated writer in the history of Syriac-speaking Christianity; in fact, it is devoid of reliable historical information concerning either Ephrem or the context in which he lived and wrote. The value of this remarkable document consists in its eloquent witness to the need of local expressions of Christianity to demonstrate conformity with the Byzantine imperial church. The compilers of the Life undertook various strategies to achieve this. They seized upon the reputation of Ephrem in native Syriac tradition to promote a way of life which he never practiced, namely, monasticism. The Life further distorts the legacy of Ephrem by capitalizing on his authority as a respected teacher (Malpana) in his tradition to enlist him in the defense of doctrines which emerged only after his death and which, in fact, he rejected in his own writings.

bib: Atwood, Preston L. “The Peshiṭta of Isaiah in Past and Present Scholarship.” Currents in Biblical Research 18:3 (2020): 211–45.
citation: Preston L. Atwood, “The Peshiṭta of Isaiah in Past and Present Scholarship,” Currents in Biblical Research 18:3 (2020): 211–45.

data.title: The Peshiṭta of Isaiah in Past and Present Scholarship
data.abstractNote: In this study I outline the scholarship pertaining to the Peshiṭta of Isaiah (S-Isa) and expound on specific topics in need of further research. I begin by recounting the process of S-Isa’s manuscript collation and its culmination in Leiden’s editio minor. Relatedly, I explain the role of citations in the patristic literature for reconstructing the original text of S-Isa. Then, I address how scholars approach the question of S-Isa’s relation to the Old Greek (G-Isa) and Targum (T-Isa) of Isaiah. I move on to summarize the studies on the translation technique of S-Isa and explain how they have aided in determining the degree to which S-Isa may have been influenced by G- and T-Isa. I continue by adumbrating the debate on the authorship and theology of S-Isa and problematizing certain assumptions brought to the discussion. I conclude by offering a few reflections on the future of S-Isa scholarship.

bib: Aubin, Jeffery. “Épicure et Bardesane Astrologues: L’exposé de Nicétas Au Livre VIII Des Recognitiones Pseudo-Clémentines.” Apocrypha 29 (2018): 97–111.
citation: Jeffery Aubin, “Épicure et Bardesane Astrologues: L’exposé de Nicétas Au Livre VIII Des Recognitiones Pseudo-Clémentines,” Apocrypha 29 (2018): 97–111.

data.title: Épicure et Bardesane astrologues: l’exposé de Nicétas au livre VIII des Recognitiones pseudo-clémentines
data.abstractNote: The atomistic theory, in the argument against astrology in Book VIII of the Recognitiones, corresponds very little to the thought of Epicurus, even though the writer of the novel claims to refute him. Scholars explain this discrepancy as a misunderstanding of Greek philosophy by the author of the Recognitiones. However, the theory refuted in Book VIII shares many similarities with the cosmology of the Syrian philosopher Bardaisan. The latter gives an important place to atoms and it is possible that the rejection of the Epicurean system is directed against astral determinism, accepted in part by Bardaisan. The discourse of Nicetas would attempt to overthrow the Bardaisanian idea that inequalities among men are the result of the power of the stars. While the Recognitiones are in agreement with the Syrian philosopher who thinks that the stars have no effect on the free will of man - reproducing his thought in Book IX - they are opposed to the idea that the inequalities among men are the result of astral fatalism. The synthesis of Epicurus and Bardaisan would aim at refuting all determinism, be it Epicurean or Bardaisanian.

data.title: Sur la chronologie de trois lettres de Théodoret de Cyr
data.abstractNote: Les lettres 66, 67 de Sirmond et XXXII du recueil de Patmos, relatives à la dédicace d'une église érigée en l'honneur des saints apôtres et prophètes, sont à ranger selon toute vraisemblance (ainsi que la lettre XXX) parmi les plus anciennes lettres de Théodoret parvenues jusqu'à nous. L'auteur trouve confirmation dé cette hypothèse dans deux passages de l'Histoire Religieuse (PG 82, 1449 AB et 1452 B).

data.title: “Abraham Has Seen You?” John 8:56-59 in a Letter of al-Ḥasan b. Ayyūb
data.abstractNote: This article tries to demonstrate that Islamic treatises against Christianity, dating from 10th century and later, offer sometimes interesting sidelights on the exegesis and the text of the New Testament. The Treatises of 'Abd al-Jabbār are well-known in this respect. This study deals with an interesting letter written by the convert al-Hassan b. Ayyūb with the intention to convince his brother that the Islam is a better alternative. In doing so, he deals with texts of the Bible, especially of the Gospels. One of these texts is John 8:56-59.

data.title: Le patriarche Sévère d’Antioche dans la liturgie maronite
data.abstractNote: Avant le milieu du XVe siècle, les Maronites n’avaient attaché presque aucune importance à l’anathème proféré par les Byzantins à l’encontre des Pères non-chalcédoniens, surtout syriaques. Ainsi fêtaient-ils sans complexe la mémoire de Jacques de Saroug, dédiaient des églises à saint Barsaum et priaient à l’aide de l’anaphore de Philoxène de Mabboug. Il en allait de même, semble-t-il, pour Sévère d’Antioche dont le nom apparaît dans des calendriers, des missels et des livres de baptême utilisés autrefois par les Maronites. C’est ce que le présent article s’efforce de montrer à partir des rares manuscrits qui ont échappé aux deux campagnes dévastatrives du délégué apostolique Eliano (1578-1582) venu en Orient purger les manuscrits des Maronites de toute influence « jacobite ».
